content.raw: What I mean is that Contour.msg is using only ROS [builtin message types](http://wiki.ros.org/msg#Fields) and doesn't depend on any other message package. It doesn't use `Float64` from `std_msgs` otherwise the line in the msg file would be `std_msgs/Float64 distance`
content.html: What I mean is that Contour.msg is using only ROS builtin message types and doesn't depend on any other message package. It doesn't use Float64 from std_msgs otherwise the line in the msg file would be std_msgs/Float64 distance

content.raw: yes, I'll remove that.
content.html: yes, I'll remove that.

content.raw: So do you mean that int32, Float64 messages used in Contour.msg are not derived from std_msgs? and taken from the ROS message primitives?
content.html: So do you mean that int32, Float64 messages used in Contour.msg are not derived from std_msgs? and taken from the ROS message primitives?

content.raw: The messages don't depend on `std_msgs` as they use ROS message primitives directly (`float64` and not `std_msgs/Float64`). I think std_msgs dependency can be removed completely from this package (CMake, python and package.xml)
content.html: The messages don't depend on std_msgs as they use ROS message primitives directly (float64 and not std_msgs/Float64). I think std_msgs dependency can be removed completely from this package (CMake, python and package.xml)

content.raw: Just a quick note to explain the original intent, not requesting changes here. The original goal of having the values for the 3 colors commented out (in the [original file](#!/osrf/servicesim/src/a3f5c71a84742ee8dc56ac8c70ffa563506101bd/competitor_example_solution/servicesim_example_python_solution/src/image_processing_example.py?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#image_processing_example.py-40)) was to allow users to test on different scenarios, e.g. the guest has a green shirt. Ideally this would be a parameter given to the node at startup rather than something that requires code changes.
content.html: Just a quick note to explain the original intent, not requesting changes here. The original goal of having the values for the 3 colors commented out (in the original file) was to allow users to test on different scenarios, e.g. the guest has a green shirt. Ideally this would be a parameter given to the node at startup rather than something that requires code changes.

content.raw: Thanks for the detailed answer! I agree with removing it.

content.raw:
If it was in the rosdep database you could install it using pip (rosdep can install packages from various package managers, both apt and pip are supported on Linux). But to release a package as a deb, all its dependencies need to be available via APT so we encourage people to not use pip dependencies.


As this module is almost unused in this package (at least in this PR), I would recommend getting rid of the dependency completely.
From what I can see there is only one function used from this module: `imutils.is_cv2()`. This is [just checking](https://github.com/jrosebr1/imutils/blob/9951937054188a4a2866ba70d296eff89179b82f/imutils/convenience.py#L154) if we are using OpenCV2 or OpenCV3.
As this package is targeting kinetic, we [already know](https://github.com/ros-perception/vision_opencv/blob/kinetic/cv_bridge/package.xml#L29) that we are using OpenCV3. If the goal is to be able  to support all ROS distros (including indigo that uses openCV2), we can use the fact that OpenCV is already imported line 17, and just check the value of `cv2.__version__` would give the answer (or `cv2.__version__[0]` if we just want to know the major). So importing a different module from pip just to do so seems a bit overkill.
content.html:
If it was in the rosdep database you could install it using pip (rosdep can install packages from various package managers, both apt and pip are supported on Linux). But to release a package as a deb, all its dependencies need to be available via APT so we encourage people to not use pip dependencies.

As this module is almost unused in this package (at least in this PR), I would recommend getting rid of the dependency completely. From what I can see there is only one function used from this module: imutils.is_cv2(). This is just checking if we are using OpenCV2 or OpenCV3. As this package is targeting kinetic, we already know that we are using OpenCV3. If the goal is to be able to support all ROS distros (including indigo that uses openCV2), we can use the fact that OpenCV is already imported line 17, and just check the value of cv2.__version__ would give the answer (or cv2.__version__[0] if we just want to know the major). So importing a different module from pip just to do so seems a bit overkill.
